import React from 'react'; import "./style.css"; export default function About() { return (

     I am a software developer currently living in Seattle. My first foray into programming was in the fall of 2012 when I entered college at the University of Washington and enrolled in an intro to Java class. At first, as I'm sure is true for many who are new to coding, I felt a bit lost navigating this new academic and theoretical territory of computer science, but, as time went on, the lightbulbs continued to go off as I grew more and more comfortable with programming and began to see the consistent and predictable patterns of logic built in to the craft. I took the next level Java class - introduction to data structures and then took the intro to web development class where I got my first taste of HTML, CSS, Javascript, and the like.

However, the idea of sitting at a computer programming all day (which is itself a bit of a mischaracterization and oversimplification of what coding is) didn't excite me enough to continue pursuing that particular academic route.

Post college I worked for a few years as the warehouse manager of a wholesale merchandising company, but I increasingly found my mind wandering more and more towards ideas that could only be brought to life as software and so I began an independent study of Python for a time, as it was a language that I knew had robust community support and, compared to Java, it was far less verbose and read more clearly to me as English.

Eventually, I resigned my position as warehouse manager with my company and ultimately decided I wanted to expand my programming knowledge base in a regimented and structured way and so I enrolled in a web development bootcamp offered by the University of Washington.

In doing so, I intended to learn more about the modern web development framework - and certainly I did - but I also discovered (or perhaps rediscovered) a passion for programming that I had not anticipated and I realized (much to my delight) just how inaccurate my prior notion of life as a developer was.

It is equal parts logical and artistic, systemic and creative. It encourages thoughtfulness and precision. For me it is rewarding in practice and it is rewarding conceptually

Perhaps best of all though, it is a tool universal enough to be applied towards creating solutions that address the things I care most about in life - everything from sustainable energy technologies to automtaing away the mundane stresses of life.
